Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Portable Doppler Wind Lidar for Atmospheric Science Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award is for the acquisition of a compact, portable Doppler Wind Lidar system. Doppler Wind Lidars use an eye-safe laser to remotely sense characteristics of the atmospheric boundary layer, such as wind, turbulence, and aerosols. This system will enhance the research capabilities at the University of Louisiana-Monroe into important topics for public safety and human health, such as the initiation of thunderstorms and air quality. The instrument will also be used as an educational tool for use by a diverse and under-served student population.

The research team will acquire a Halo Photonics Stream Line XR, which is a pulsed Doppler Wind Lidar with an eye-safe laser, high pulse rate, low pulse energy, and coherent heterodyne detection. The team will incorporate the Lidar into a package with existing instrumentation such as a microwave radiometer, rawinsonde system, and surface instrumentation so it can be used in a mobile configuration for field studies or at a fixed-site location on campus. Topics of study that will be enhanced by the acquisition include: 1) Convective initiation and onset of severe weather, 2) Lake and sea breeze circulations and coastal processes, 3) Precipitation and cloud physics, and 4) Aerosol science and air pollution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led to the acquisition of a scanning Doppler wind lidar for planetary boundary layer studies to improve understanding of (1) thunderstorm formation and the onset of severe weather, (2) circulations forced by changes in land-cover or land-type, (3) precipitation, and (4) aerosols and air pollution. The lidar and supporting equipment are mounted in a 4x4 truck bed using a custom-fabricated, shock absorbing frame to create a state-of-the-art mobile atmospheric profiling laboratory which allows for fast deployments in rapidly changing weather scenarios. Additional instrumentation on the truck includes a weather balloon system and surface instrumentation. Complementary instrumentation also available includes a microwave radiometer and a polarimetric S-band Doppler weather radar.

To date, the lidar has collected low-level wind observations near an EF-3 tornado, observed wild-fire smoke within the boundary layer, and examined low-level jet development during the afternoon-to-evening boundary layer transition over an inland water feature. Preliminary observations from the tornado deployment indicate low-level winds rapidly accelerated just prior to tornado development.

The lidar has been incorporated into the teaching portfolio of the department, providing experiential educational opportunities to a number of undergraduate students, including many students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. And since it is portable, the lidar can be used as an outreach and recruiting tool for the atmospheric sciences.
